description: The Indonesian government releases a document that outlines the distribution of vaccines produced by PT Bio Farma on 2 January 2021. description: On March 31 2020, the Indonesian government signed a Government Regulation on Large-Scale Social Restrictions. The regulation allows "Large-Scale Social Restrictions" as defined in Law No.6/2020 on Health Quarantine to take into effect, under the condition that regions wishing to apply the policy obtain approval from the Ministry of Health/central government. The law covers several types of policies, such as isolation, house quarantine, regional quarantine, large-scale social restrictions and lockdowns, etc.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: A general law on health quarantine (UU No. 6/2018). The law requires a regulation to allow it to take into effect (which will be coded as update afterwards). The law covers several types of policies, such as isolation, house quarantine, regional quarantine, large-scale social restrictions, etc. The law was put into effect on March 31 by the issuance of regulation on Large-Scale Social Restrictions.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 31, the Indonesian government signed a Government Regulation on Large-Scale Social Restrictions. The regulation allows "Large-Scale Social Restrictions" as defined in Law No.6/2020 on Health Quarantine to take into effect, under the condition that regions wishing to apply the policy obtain approval from the Ministry of Health/central government.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On April 3 2020, Indonesia's health minister signed Peraturan Menteri No. 9/2020 on the Guidelines for Large-Scale Social Restrictions. The document outlines the criteria that local administrations should fulfill in order to enact the large-scale social restriction (lockdown) policy in their region. description: The Indonesian government enacts a 'Pemberlakuan Pembatasan Kegiatan Masyarakat Berbasis Mikro' - loosely translated as lockdown that is implemented until the micro level - from February 9 - 22, 2021. This policy mandates that micro-level units of government, such as districts and sub-districts, villages, and RT/RW (neighbourhoods). Besides a lockdown, the policy also includes different intensities of health monitoring, quarantine, curfews, and closure of public spaces depending on different levels of virus spread in the respective areas (i.e. green, yellow, orange, and red zones). The policy is enacted after a previously similar policy, which was enacted until the city/regency level.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Indonesia is providing an IDR 10.3 trillion stimulus to the domestic tourism sector in the form of discounted ticket prices for 10 tourist destinations, such as  Batam, Denpasar, Yogyakarta, Labuan Bajo, Lombok, Malang, Manado, Lake Toba (Silangit Airport), Tanjung Pandan, and Tanjungpinang, which applies  from March to May 2020. 

Ticket prices for low-cost airlines are discounted by 50%, medium-service by 48%, and full-service by 45%. Specifically for this ticket price discount, the stimulus fund comes from the IDR 444.39 billion-state budget (APBN) for a discounted value of 30% and 25% of passengers per flight. Additionally, there are additional ticket discounts paid by Angkasa Pura I and Angkasa Pura II in the amount of Rp100 billion and PT Pertamina (Persero) in the amount of Rp260 billion through avtur price discounts, so the total ticket price stimulus is IDR 960 billion so that the ticket price can be discounted by 50%.
type_text: This is to provide stimulus to the domestic tourism sector in the form of discounted ticket prices.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 6, the Indonesian government rolled out a health protocol on handling the Covid-19. The release of this health protocol is accompanied with 4 other protocols (on communication, border monitoring, education, as well as transportation and public spaces).
type_text: The policy is a protocol that outlines how the public should act in responding to the pandemic (and who to reach out to).
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 6, the Indonesian government released a communication protocol that outlines how government officials should convey information on the Covid-19 pandemic to the public. The protocol prescribes the creation of a communication team and that government officials should abide by the following narratives in making statements: a) that the government is serious and capable in handling the pandemic; b) that people should remain calm but aware; and c) that the Covid-19 can be cured. The release of this protocol was accompanied by 4 other protocols.
type_text: The policy is a guideline for government officials who are going to release information on the Covid-19 to the public. I regard this a public policy as it affects the public is going to receive official statements about the pandemic and the public's responses to it. (for context, the issue of the Indonesian government's transparency is currently criticized)
enforcer: National Government

description: On March 6, the Indonesian government released a protocol for educational institutions. The protocol consists of procedures that educational institutions should take to prevent the transmission of the Covid-19. The release of the protocol was accompanied by 4 other protocols.

description: The OJK is issuing OJK Regulation No.11/POJK.03/2020 on National Economic Stimulus as a Countercyclical Policy of Coronavirus Disease 2019 Infection Impact (“POJK 11/2020”). POJK 11/2020 primarily is intended to support economic growth for debtors impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, including for Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (“MSME”) debtors, conducted through policies on asset quality determination and credit restructuring and financing. Based on POJK 11/2020, banks may implement policies to support the economic growth stimulus by conducting the above by still considering the implementation of risk management of banks and also having guidelines to establish debtors and MSME debtors based on the criteria and sectors impacted by COVID-19.
type_text: This policy falls into economic resources. It is issued by the Otoritas Jasa Keuangan (OJK).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Indonesian National Police issued a declaration ("Maklumat Kapolri") to ban the hoarding of basic goods on March 19. The declaration is an emphasis on Law No. 7/2014 (Article 29) that prohibits the hoarding of goods/necessities in times of scarcity.

enforcer: National Government,Police

description: Indonesia's Ministry of Law and Human Rights issued a policy to release around 30,000 prisoners as an effort to prevent the spread of Covid-19. The prisoners must meet several conditions in order to be eligible for the release: a) have served 2/3 of their sentences by December 31, 2020; b) for minors, having served 1/3 of their sentences by December 31, 2020; c) is not affected by PP 99/2012 (for prisoners applying for assimilation), not affected by PP No. 12/1999 (for those applying for integration), not serving subsidiary sentences, and is not a foreign national; d) must stay at home; and e) obtain a letter of assimilation from the head of their respective correctional facilities (or letter of integration from the general director for those applying for integration).
type_text: The policy releases prisoners ahead of their sentence time
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Indonesia is providing a new fiscal stimulus (Vol 2) of IDR 22.9 trillion. The new stimulus includes the following:

1. Income Tax Law No. 21 (PPh Pasal 21) - Up to 100% or IDR 200 million income tax exemption for workers in process manufacturing industry from April 2020 to September 2020.
2. Income Tax Law No. 22 (PPh Pasal 22) - Import tax exemption from April 2020 to September 2020.
3. Income Tax Law No. 25 (PPh Pasal 25) - Income tax exemption from April 2020 to September 2020.
4. Value-added tax exemption from April 2020 to September 2020.
type_text: Fiscal Stimulus Vol 2 of IDR 22.9 trillion by the Ministry of Finance.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Indonesia is providing an additional stimulus package amounting to IDR 405.1 trillion (2.6% of GDP) with the following details:
1. IDR 75 trillion for the health sector, which includes protection for healthcare workers, purchase of medical equipments, reparation of healthcare facilities, and doctors' incentives.
2. Social Safety Net of IDR 110 trillion consisted of food assistance programs, pre-employment cards, and electricity.
3. Tax reliefs and KUR (Credits for People's Businesses) amounting to IDR 75 trillion, which includes permanent reductions of the corporate income tax rate from 25 percent to 22 percent in 2020-21 and 20 percent starting in 2022. 
4. Funding for the national economic recovery program amounting to IDR 150 trillion.
type_text: Issued by the Ministry of Finance, this is the third COVID-19-related fiscal stimulus after the first 2 fiscal stimulus amounting to IDR 33.2 trillion.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 6, Indonesia's Ministry of Religious Affairs issued guidelines for religious activities in the upcoming month of Ramadan. The guidelines include recommendations that a) Muslims have meals individually or with their nuclear families; b) Muslims not have congregational prayers, including Eid prayers (at the mosque where mass gatherings occur); c) all iftar and other ceremonial gatherings be suspended; d) Muslims not conduct Iktikaf at mosques; e) ritual parades be suspended; f) 'halal bi halal' be conducted through calls; and g) Muslims pay their zakat before the month of Ramadan starts.

description: The Indonesian Covid-19 Task Force advises that participants of political campaigns ahead of the regional elections wear masks, gloves, face shields and/or be equipped with hand sanitizer, Sept 10. UPDATE: As part of "Operasi Yustisi," from September 14, this policy will include increased disciplinary measures/sanctions, such as fines, social and administrational punishments, to imprisonment if necessary.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Indonesia's COVID-19 Task Force announced social distancing measures for people who choose to do exercise outside, June 28. The protocols include maintaining a distance of at least 5 meters for walks, 2 meters for stationary (non-mobile) activities (e.g. yoga, stretching), 10 meters for jogs, and 20 meters for cycling. UPDATE: As part of Indonesia's "Operasi Yustisi", from September 14 there will be increased disciplinary measures, such as social and administrational sanctions, fines, to imprisonment.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 9, 2021, the municipal government of Tasikmalaya limits the operations of food vendors during Ramadhan. Ramadhan takes place from April 12 to May 12, 2021.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Municipal Government

description: As part of the province's second lockdown, the provincial government of DKI Jakarta closes non-essential business services, from September 14 - 28, 2020. These include full closures of recreational services and arenas, public sports areas, parks, and party (i.e. wedding) venues. Restaurants and cafes can open for takeaways and deliveries only. Certain non-essential businesses may operate with a limited capacity on-site of 25%.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants

enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force
